intro: Limniris pseudacorus, commonly known as the water parsnip, is a flowering plant native to Europe and parts of Asia. It is a member of the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbel-shaped flowers. The plant typically grows in wet or moist habitats such as marshes and stream banks. Its leaves are compound, with finely divided segments, and it produces small, white to greenish flowers that bloom in late spring. The plant is often found in disturbed or nutrient-rich soils and can be invasive in certain regions.
